body.note: these six pages all one piece
body.head: Fancies at Navesink
body.note: heavy black the same as usual
body.head: The Pilot in the Mist.

lg.l:
Steaming the northern rapids—(an old
St. Lawrence reminiscence,

A sudden memory⹀flash comes back, I know
not why,

Here waiting for the sunrise, gazing from this
hill;*),

Again 'tis just at morning—a heavy haze
contends with daybreak,

Again the trembling, laboring vessel veers
me—
we —I press through
foaming foam⹀dash'd rocks
that almost touch me.

Again I mark where aft the small thin
Indian helmsman,

Looms in the mist, with brown elate and
governing hand.

lg.head: Had I the Choice.
lg.l: Had I the choice to tally greatest bards,
To limn their portraits, stately, beautiful, and emulate at will,

Homer with all his warrs wars and warriors,
Hector, Achilles, Ajax,

Or Shakspere's woe⹀entangled Hamlet, Lear,
Othello—Tennyson's fair ladies,

Metre or wit to the best or choice concert
to wield
or in perfect rhyme, delight
of singers;
These, these, O sea, all these I'd gladly barter,

Would you the undulation of one wave, its
trick to me transfer

Could you but Or breathe ‸ one breath ‸of yours upon this
verse,
And leave its odor there.

lg.head: Last of ebb, and daylight waning.

lg.l: Last of ebb, and daylight waning.

Scented sea⹀cool brine wind landward making, smells of
sedge and salt incoming.

With many a half⹀caught voice sent up from
the eddies,

Many a muffled confession—many a sob
and whisper'd word,
As of speakers far or hid.

How they sweep down and out! how they
mutter!

Poets unnamed—artists greatest of any, with
all theircherish'd lost designs,

Love unreturn'd—‸—a chorus ofage's complaints—hope's last
words.

Some suicide's despairing cry, Away to the
boundless waste, and never again return.
On to oblivion then!
On, on, and do your part, ye burying, ebb!‸ebbing tide!
On for your time, ye furious debouch√©
Nor you alone, twilight and burying eddies,ebb,

I know, divine deceitful ones your glamour's
seeming,

Duly from you, by you,‸alone, the inborne tides
again—duly the hinges turning,

Duly the blendedneeded blending discord⹀parts
offsetting, blending,

Weaving from you, from sleep, andNight, from
Death itself,
A rhythmus of Birth eternal.

lg.head: Proudly the flood comes in.
lg.l:
Proudly the flood comes in, shouting, foaming,
advancing,

Long it holds at the high, with bosom
broad outswelling,—

All throbs, dilates—the farms, woods, streets
of cities—workmen at their work;

Mainsails, topsails, jibs, appear in the offing—
the steamers', with pann with pennants of smoke—
—and under the forenoon sun,

Freighted with human lives, gaily the outward
bound, gaily the inward bound,
Flaunting from many a spar the flag I love.

lg.head: By that long trainscan of waves.
lg.l:
By that long trainscan of
waves, myself call'd back, resumed
upon myself,

WithIn every crest some undulating light
or shade—some retrospect,

Joys, travels, studies—silent panoramas—
scenes ephemeral, mournful,

The long⹀past war, the battles, hospital sights,
the wounded and the dead;

Myself through every by-gone phase—my
idle youth—old age at hand

My three-score years of life summ'd up
and more and past,
By any grand ideal tried, ‸intentionless the whole‸ a nothing

And ‸haply yet some drop drop within God's scheme's
ensemble—some wave, or part of wave,
Like one of yours, ye multitudinous ocean

lg.head: Then Last of all.
lg.l: Then last of all, laving these shores, this hill
Of you O tides, the mystic human meaning;

Only by law of you, your swell and ebb, enclosing
me the same,
The brain that shapes, the voice that chants this song.
lg.note: *Navesink—a sea-side mountain, lower entrance of New York bay.
